bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, March 3, 1949

div1.p: Hench is concerned that there is only one copy of Moran's yellow fever manuscript, and so urges Moran to send it to him to have copies made. Hench would like to have a copy of Moran's manuscript to compare with his notes, and as a basis to formulate questions for Moran.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, March 3, 1949
div1.opener:
March 3, 1949
Mr. John J. Moran
Calle 25 No. 804
Entre B y C
Vedado, Havana
Cuba
My dear Johnny:
div1.p:
Will you please do me one great big favor? You don't realize how
important, at least in my opinion, is your manuscript on “My Date with Walter
Reed and Yellow Jack”. Incidentally, I like that title very much. Won't you
please let me read it? I am extremely anxious to do so so that you and I can
discuss it while we are both together in the land of the living. Please, please
do this, Johnny. I will abide entirely with your decision as to whether it
should be published, but please let me take a look at it.

I know how one feels when he has finished a paper. One has a mixed
feeling of satisfaction and dissatisfaction. Maybe your dissatisfaction is
over-stressed. Maybe very minor changes could be made. I can just hear you
say “No, I am done with it, I couldn't change another word.” If you aren't
willing to let the editors here see it, please let me see it in confidence.
If you do send it, please mail it registered mail. In my opinion, it is a
very precious document. Despite our long talks together, it is not only pos-
sible but most likely that you have certain data therein that you and I just
have never happened to discuss. I have kept every note of yours very carefully
but every now and then when I go to them for something I am amazed to find
that either we didn't discuss your view of it or I made no note. You simply
must not wait until you are gone for me to see it! You can't do that to your
old friend!

The rest of your letter depressed me but I was not surprised. I am
quite disappointed but also not surprised that the funds allotted by the Ministry
of Finance for the preservation of the caseta have disappeared; at least I now
have another excuse to come to Cuba in the next few months, as I shall try to do.

When you have time, I should like to get the photograph of your
Congressional Medal but there is no hurry. I agree that Doctor Nogueira can help
copy the newspaper articles better than you can but at least I have the dates
and know now where they are so that if necessary, I can get that when I come.

I have been extremely busy recently. I am General Chairman of an
International Congress to be held at the Waldorf in May. It is a terrible
job and I will be thankful when it is over. Also our research work here has
been going very well indeed, which has kept me very busy. We plan to report
this research in the spring and it may be of such a nature that even you will
hear about it. Please give our best regards to your good wife and please let
me hear from you shortly.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
